results.title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
results.abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

results.title: Viral Infections and Gene Variant Are Linked to Child Hepatitis Cases
results.abstract: Some of the children were infected with adeno-associated virus 2 and shared a relatively uncommon gene variant, according to two small studies.

multimedia.caption: The computer model of adeno-associated virus type 2.
The computer model of adeno-associated virus type 2.
The computer model of adeno-associated virus type 2.

results.title: Buzz Aldrin’s Space Memorabilia Sells for More Than $8 Million
results.abstract: A jacket that the astronaut wore during the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969 and his Presidential Medal of Freedom were among the items auctioned off by Sotheby’s in New York City.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Aldrin during the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969.
Mr. Aldrin during the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969.
Mr. Aldrin during the Apollo 11 mission to the moon in 1969.

results.title: How Is Climate Change Affecting Floods?
results.abstract: Like other extreme weather disasters, flooding involves a number of competing factors that may affect its frequency and intensity.

multimedia.caption: Flooding on Forest Park Parkway in St. Louis after heavy rains on Tuesday morning.
Flooding on Forest Park Parkway in St. Louis after heavy rains on Tuesday morning.
Flooding on Forest Park Parkway in St. Louis after heavy rains on Tuesday morning.

results.title: Few Parents Intend to Have Very Young Children Vaccinated Against Covid
results.abstract: In a new survey, 43 percent of parents of children ages 6 months through 4 years said they would refuse the shots for their kids. An additional 27 percent were uncertain.

multimedia.caption: An 8-month-old received a Covid vaccine in Hatfield, Pa., last month.

results.title: Fentanyl From the Government? A Vancouver Experiment Aims to Stop Overdoses
results.abstract: A city on the forefront of harm reduction has taken the concept to a new level in an effort to address the growing toxicity of street drugs.

multimedia.caption: A nurse at the Crosstown Clinic, a supervised injection site in Vancouver, British Columbia, handed out a syringe of medical-grade heroin to a patient in May.

results.title: Biden’s Drug Czar Is Leading the Charge for a ‘Harm Reduction’ Approach
results.abstract: Experts describe the president’s drug control strategy as the most progressive since Richard Nixon appointed the nation’s first drug czar in 1971.

multimedia.copyright: Sophie Park for The New York Times
Sophie Park for The New York Times
Sophie Park for The New York Times

results.title: W.H.O. Declares Monkeypox Spread a Global Health Emergency
results.abstract: There have been more than 16,000 cases in 75 countries, overwhelmingly among men who have sex with men.

multimedia.caption: Monkeypox vaccines were still in short supply when the World Health Organization declared the virus’s spread a global health emergency.
Monkeypox vaccines were still in short supply when the World Health Organization declared the virus’s spread a global health emergency.
Monkeypox vaccines were still in short supply when the World Health Organization declared the virus’s spread a global health emergency.

results.title: Four Things Nations Can Do to Conserve Energy
results.abstract: European Union officials have called on countries in the bloc to sharply reduce their natural gas consumption. These are some of the strategies they could use.

results.title: After Roe, Pregnant Women With Cancer Diagnoses May Face Wrenching Choices
results.abstract: Urgent questions arise about how care of pregnant women with cancer will change in states where women are unable to terminate pregnancies.

multimedia.caption: Half of cancers in pregnant women are breast cancer, but many others occur and complicate an already complex medical situation.
Half of cancers in pregnant women are breast cancer, but many others occur and complicate an already complex medical situation.
Half of cancers in pregnant women are breast cancer, but many others occur and complicate an already complex medical situation.

results.title: How the Government Is Failing Americans Uprooted by Calamity
results.abstract: Climate change is creating a growing class of displaced Americans, and the federal government is struggling to decide how to help them.
results.byline: By Christopher Flavelle and Edmund D. Fountain

multimedia.caption: Betty Swope at her home in Lake Charles, La. She moved back in before damage from Hurricane Laura was fully repaired because her time in rent-free emergency shelter had run out.
Betty Swope at her home in Lake Charles, La. She moved back in before damage from Hurricane Laura was fully repaired because her time in rent-free emergency shelter had run out.
Betty Swope at her home in Lake Charles, La. She moved back in before damage from Hurricane Laura was fully repaired because her time in rent-free emergency shelter had run out.

results.title: Like the Rest of Us, Biden Learns to Live With the Risks of the Virus
results.abstract: The president’s symptoms improved somewhat, a day after he tested positive for Covid-19.
results.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

multimedia.caption: President Biden held a Presidential Medal of Freedom ceremony this month at the White House, where he embraced and kissed many of the recipients. The White House has dropped many of the extraordinary pandemic safety measures around the president.

President Biden held a Presidential Medal of Freedom ceremony this month at the White House, where he embraced and kissed many of the recipients. The White House has dropped many of the extraordinary pandemic safety measures around the president.

results.title: Rare Case of Polio Prompts Alarm and an Urgent Investigation in New York
results.abstract: Health officials in Rockland County offered pop-up polio vaccinations and urged the public to get shots as they investigated whether the disease had spread to others.
results.byline: By Jesse McKinley and Nate Schweber

multimedia.caption: The health department in Rockland County, northwest of New York City, urged people there to be vaccinated against polio after the first U.S. case in about a decade was discovered.

results.title: Combined nasal and throat testing swabs would detect more Omicron infections, two papers suggest.
results.abstract: The papers, which have not yet been published in scientific journals, suggest that testing just a single type of sample is likely to miss a large share of infections.

multimedia.caption: Administering a throat swab at a drive-in coronavirus testing center in Los Angeles in 2020.
Administering a throat swab at a drive-in coronavirus testing center in Los Angeles in 2020.
Administering a throat swab at a drive-in coronavirus testing center in Los Angeles in 2020.

results.title: See How Far Water Levels in Lake Mead Have Fallen
results.abstract: New satellite images of the reservoir, a critical source of water for 25 million people, reveal dangerously low water levels.

results.title: Patrick J. Michaels, Vocal Outlier on Climate Change, Dies at 72
results.abstract: He thought the conversation around global warming was alarmist, and his scientific credentials made him a go-to expert for those who played down the threat.

multimedia.caption: The climatologist Patrick J. Michaels in 2017. He was a visible and polarizing figure in the climate change debate.
The climatologist Patrick J. Michaels in 2017. He was a visible and polarizing figure in the climate change debate.
The climatologist Patrick J. Michaels in 2017. He was a visible and polarizing figure in the climate change debate.

results.title: What to Know About the Marburg Virus Disease
results.abstract: Two people infected with the virus died in Ghana last month, though no other cases were found, experts said. The disease’s fatality rate is high.

multimedia.caption: Researchers gathering bats in 2018 at Queen Elizabeth National Park in Uganda to study the animals’ role in transmission of the Marburg virus.

results.title: First Polio Case in Nearly a Decade Is Detected in New York State
results.abstract: A man who lives in Rockland County was infected by someone who received the oral polio vaccine, which is no longer used in the United States, officials said.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: This 1964 microscope image shows damage from the polio virus to human spinal cord tissue.
This 1964 microscope image shows damage from the polio virus to human spinal cord tissue.

results.title: A Painful Deadline Nears as Colorado River Reservoirs Run Critically Low
results.abstract: The federal government has told states to agree on urgent water cuts to ensure dams can keep generating power. Researchers say reductions once considered “unthinkable” may be necessary in the long term.

multimedia.caption: A photo from March shows Lone Rock Beach on Lake Powell in Utah, an area that used to be underwater.
A photo from March shows Lone Rock Beach on Lake Powell in Utah, an area that used to be underwater.
A photo from March shows Lone Rock Beach on Lake Powell in Utah, an area that used to be underwater.

results.title: Monarch Butterflies Are Endangered, Leading Wildlife Monitor Says
results.abstract: Researchers cited climate change and habitat loss. But they also said the public can help give the insects a boost.

results.title: An An, World’s Oldest Giant Male Panda in Captivity, Dies at 35
results.abstract: The animal was euthanized in Hong Kong on Thursday because of his deteriorating health, a statement said.

multimedia.caption: An An at Ocean Park in Hong Kong in 2020. In recent weeks, he was refusing solid foods. His diet swayed far from the daily intake of 30 pounds of bamboo that giant pandas normally eat.
An An at Ocean Park in Hong Kong in 2020. In recent weeks, he was refusing solid foods. His diet swayed far from the daily intake of 30 pounds of bamboo that giant pandas normally eat.

results.title: F.D.A. Seeks Outside Review of Troubled Food and Tobacco Units
results.abstract: The agency’s commissioner asked an external foundation to examine its operations in the wake of the baby formula and vaping crises.

results.title: Robert F. Curl Jr., Nobel Prize Winner in Chemistry, Dies at 88
results.abstract: He and three others discovered unexpectedly simple carbon molecules called buckyballs (think of a soccer ball), spurring explorations of nanotechnology.

multimedia.caption: Robert F. Curl Jr. in 2011. His discovery of long carbon chains, which was made alongside several other scientists, was serendipitous.

results.title: Can Fashion Influencers Persuade Us to Consume Less? A Times Virtual Event
results.abstract: Join Vanessa Friedman on July 28 as she explores how popular culture and the influencer economy might shift the industry toward responsible fashion.

results.title: Women Face Risks as Doctors Struggle With Medical Exceptions on Abortion
results.abstract: Of the 13 states with trigger bans, all make exceptions for abortions to save the life of the mother. But what defines a medical emergency?
results.byline: By J. David Goodman and Azeen Ghorayshi
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

multimedia.caption: After a critical care nurse in Texas became pregnant, her water broke at 19 weeks. When doctors would not conduct an abortion until she was actively sick, she and her husband flew to Colorado for the procedure.
multimedia.copyright: Liz Moskowitz for The New York Times
